docs.title: 📖 About Hunter: The Reckoning 5E
docs.text:
Hunter: The Reckoning 5th Edition is the latest iteration of the classic World of Darkness game about ordinary people who have glimpsed the supernatural truth and taken up arms against the darkness. The Reckoning calls. Hunters answer.

Key H5E mechanics Herald implements: - Edge - Supernatural awareness granting reroll capabilities - Desperation - Growing recklessness with escalating consequences - Conviction - Moral compass tracking Hunter's code - Creeds - Philosophical approaches to the Hunt - Dangers - Environmental and supernatural complications

Herald was built by active H5E players running their own chronicles. The Reckoning doesn't wait for corporate timelines. When official tools are absent, Hunters build their own.

docs.title: The Philosophy
docs.text:
Pattern observed: When tools are absent, Hunters build them.

Herald exists as proof. Community-driven. Open source. Free forever. Built by Hunters who couldn't wait. We needed character tracking. We needed H5E-specific dice mechanics. We needed something that understood Edge, Desperation, and the weight of Conviction.

So we built it. And we hunt with you.

Core principles: - ✅ Mechanical accuracy - Edge, Desperation, and messy crits work correctly - ✅ Zero setup - Add bot, create character, start hunting - ✅ Privacy-focused - Local database, no external data collection - ✅ Open source - Community-driven development - ✅ Free forever - No premium tiers, no paywalls, no subscriptions

docs.title: Command Syntax Conventions
docs.text: Herald uses Discord's slash command system. Here's how to read command syntax:

docs.title: Required Parameters
docs.text:
Parameters without brackets are required:

/create name:Raven

You must provide a name.

docs.title: Optional Parameters
docs.text:
Parameters in [square brackets] are optional:

/roll_char character:Raven attribute:Dexterity [skill:Stealth]

You can include or omit the skill parameter.

docs.title: Choices
docs.text:
Some parameters have predefined choices shown in a dropdown:

/roll_char attribute:Dexterity  ← Shows dropdown of all 9 attributes
/skill_template template:Balanced  ← Shows: Balanced, Specialist, Jack-of-all-trades

docs.title: Autocomplete
docs.text:
Character names and skills use autocomplete - start typing and Herald suggests options:

/sheet character:Ra  ← Shows "Raven", "Rachel", etc.

Privacy

Use the ephemeral:True parameter on commands like /sheet to keep results private!

docs.title: Character Commands
docs.text: Character commands handle creating, viewing, switching, and deleting your Hunter characters. These are the core commands you'll use to manage your character data in Herald.

docs.title: /create
docs.text: Create a new Hunter character sheet.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: /create name:CharacterName [attributes...] [goals...]

docs.title: Required Parameters
docs.text: • name - Character name (2-32 characters, must be unique per user)

docs.title: Optional Attribute Parameters
docs.text:
All attributes default to 1 if not specified:

Physical: - strength - 1-5 (default: 1) - dexterity - 1-5 (default: 1) - stamina - 1-5 (default: 1)

Social: - charisma - 1-5 (default: 1) - manipulation - 1-5 (default: 1) - composure - 1-5 (default: 1)

Mental: - intelligence - 1-5 (default: 1) - wits - 1-5 (default: 1) - resolve - 1-5 (default: 1)

docs.title: Optional Goal Parameters
docs.text:
• ambition - Long-term goal (max 200 characters)
  • desire - Short-term goal (max 200 characters)
  • drive - Reason for hunting (max 200 characters)

docs.title: Automatic Calculations
docs.text: Herald automatically sets: - Health = Stamina + 3 - Willpower = Resolve + Composure - All skills = 0 (set later with /skill_set) - Desperation = 0 - Danger = 0 - Experience = 0

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Minimal creation: 

/create name:Sarah Martinez
Creates character with all attributes at 1, Health 4, Willpower 2.

Full creation: 

/create name:Marcus Kane
        strength:3 dexterity:3 stamina:2
        charisma:2 manipulation:3 composure:3
        intelligence:2 wits:3 resolve:2
        ambition:"Destroy the vampire court"
        desire:"Find their haven"
Creates complete character with custom attributes and goals.

Balanced hunter: 

/create name:Elena Vasquez
        strength:2 dexterity:3 stamina:3
        charisma:3 manipulation:2 composure:2
        intelligence:2 wits:3 resolve:2

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Character names must be unique per user
  • You can create multiple characters
  • The new character is automatically set as your active character
  • All skills start at 0 - use /skill_set to add dots
  • See First Character Guide for creation walkthrough

docs.title: Common Errors
docs.text:
• "Name already exists" - You already have a character with that name
  • "Name too short/long" - Must be 2-32 characters
  • "Invalid attribute value" - Attributes must be 1-5

Your active character is used automatically in all commands: - /sheet shows active character - /roll uses active character's stats - /skill_set modifies active character - All commands operate on active character by default

docs.title: /delete
docs.text: Delete your active character.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: /delete

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: None - deletes active character.

docs.title: Behavior
docs.text:
1. Shows confirmation dialog with character name
  2. Requires clicking "Confirm Delete" button
  3. Timeout after 30 seconds (auto-cancels)
  4. Permanently removes character and ALL associated data

docs.title: Confirmation Dialog
docs.text:
⚠️ Delete Character: Sarah Martinez

This will permanently delete this character and all associated data.
This action cannot be undone.

[Confirm Delete] [Cancel]

docs.title: What Gets Deleted
docs.text: Permanently removes: - Character sheet - All skills - All Edges and Perks - All specialties - XP log history - Everything associated with the character

docs.title: After Deletion
docs.text:
• If you have other characters, one becomes active automatically
  • If this was your only character, you'll need to /create a new one
  • No way to recover deleted characters

docs.title: Safety Features
docs.text:
• Confirmation required - Can't accidentally delete
  • 30-second timeout - Dialog expires if no action
  • Clear warnings - Multiple reminders about permanence

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Removing old/unused characters
  • Starting fresh with new concept
  • Cleaning up test characters

Warning

Deletion is permanent. There is no undo. Make sure you want to delete before confirming.

docs.title: Development Commands
docs.text: Development commands handle character progression: improving attributes, raising skills, adding specialties, and managing experience points.

docs.title: /attributes
docs.text:
Set attribute ratings.

Usage: 

/attributes attribute:NAME dots:X

Parameters: - attribute (required): strength, dexterity, stamina, charisma, manipulation, composure, intelligence, wits, resolve - dots (required): 1-5

Auto-Calculations: - Stamina change → Health = Stamina + 3 - Composure/Resolve change → Willpower = Resolve + Composure

Examples: 

/attributes attribute:Dexterity dots:4
/attributes attribute:Strength dots:3

XP Cost: New rating × 4 XP (automatically deducted if XP available)

docs.title: /skill_set
docs.text:
Set skill dots.

Usage: 

/skill_set skill:NAME dots:X

Parameters: - skill (required): Dropdown with all 27 skills - dots (required): 0-5

Skills: - Physical: Athletics, Brawl, Craft, Driving, Firearms, Larceny, Melee, Stealth, Survival - Social: Animal Ken, Etiquette, Insight, Intimidation, Leadership, Performance, Persuasion, Streetwise, Subterfuge - Mental: Academics, Awareness, Finance, Investigation, Medicine, Occult, Politics, Science, Technology

Examples: 

/skill_set skill:Firearms dots:3
/skill_set skill:Investigation dots:4

XP Cost: New rating × 2 XP (automatically deducted)

docs.title: /specialty
docs.text:
Manage skill specialties.

Usage: 

/specialty action:ACTION [skill:NAME] [specialty:NAME]

Actions: - view - Show all specialties - add - Add specialty to skill - remove - Remove specialty

Requirements: - Skill must have 1+ dots - Max specialties = skill dots (minimum 1)

Examples: 

/specialty action:view
/specialty action:add skill:Firearms specialty:Pistols
/specialty action:remove skill:Firearms specialty:Pistols

XP Cost: 3 XP each (automatically deducted)

docs.title: /xp
docs.text:
Manage experience points.

Usage: 

/xp action:ACTION [amount:X] [reason:"text"]

Actions: - view - Show XP totals and history - add - Add XP (Storyteller) - spend - Manually spend XP - set - Set total XP (Storyteller)

Examples:

docs.title: Dice Commands
docs.text: Dice commands handle all rolling mechanics in Herald, implementing the full H5E dice pool system with Desperation, Danger, and difficulty tracking.

docs.title: /roll
docs.text: Roll dice using Hunter: The Reckoning 5E mechanics.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: /roll pool:X [difficulty:Y] [desperate:true/false] [comment:"text"]

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• pool (required) - Number of dice to roll (1-100, typically 1-20)
  • difficulty (optional) - Target successes needed (0-6, default: 0)
  • 0 = Automatic
  • 1 = Simple
  • 2 = Standard
  • 3 = Hard
  • 4 = Extreme
  • 5 = Nearly Impossible
  • 6 = Legendary
  • desperate (optional) - Add Desperation dice (true/false, default: false)
  • comment (optional) - Description of the roll

docs.title: H5E Dice Mechanics
docs.text:
Success Counting: - 1-5 = Failure - 6-9 = Success (1 success each) - 10 = Success (1 success, can form critical pairs) - Pair of 10s = Critical (+2 additional successes)

Desperation Dice: When desperate:true: - Adds your Desperation rating as extra dice (orange colored) - Visually distinct from regular dice - Subject to Overreach and Despair consequences

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Basic roll: 

/roll pool:5 difficulty:2 comment:Pick a lock
Rolls 5 dice, need 2+ successes.

Desperate roll: 

/roll pool:6 desperate:true difficulty:3 comment:Must hit the vampire!
Rolls 6 regular dice + Desperation dice, need 3+ successes.

Simple difficulty check: 

/roll pool:7 difficulty:1 comment:Spot the ambush
Roll 7 dice, only need 1 success.

No difficulty (check for crits): 

/roll pool:8 comment:Damage roll
Just count successes, no target difficulty.

docs.title: Visual Output
docs.text:
Herald displays rolls with emoji dice:

Regular Dice: - ⭐ Critical 10 (part of pair) - 🎯 Success (6-9) - ⚫ Failure (1-5) - 💥 Botch 1

Desperation Dice: - ✨ Critical 10 - 🟡 Success (6-9) - 🟠 Failure (2-5) - 🔥 Botch 1

Sorted Display: 

Regular: ⭐⭐🎯🎯⚫
Desperation: ✨🟡🔥

Successes: 6 (includes +2 from critical pair)

docs.title: Result Embeds
docs.text:
Success (Green): 

🎯 Success - Breaking down the door
Pool: 6 dice | Difficulty: 2
Result: 4 successes (margin +2)

Critical Success (Gold): 

⭐ Critical Success!
Pool: 8 dice | Difficulty: 3
Result: 7 successes (margin +4)
Critical pairs: 1

Failure (Gray): 

💔 Failure - Picking the lock
Pool: 5 dice | Difficulty: 3
Result: 1 success (margin -2)

Messy Critical (Orange warning): 

⚠️ MESSY CRITICAL
Desperation dice contributed to critical!
Supernatural traces left behind.
Witnesses see something unnatural.

Overreach Warning (Red/Orange): 

⚠️ OVERREACH
Rolled 2 ones on Desperation dice!
Choose: Accept success + gain 2 Danger
     OR Enter Despair

Automatic Despair (Dark Red): 

💀 AUTOMATIC DESPAIR
Failed roll with Desperation ones!
Drive lost. Must complete Redemption.

docs.title: Desperation Consequences
docs.text:
When using desperate:true:

Messy Critical: - If Desperation dice form/contribute to critical pair - Success, but supernatural power shows - Complications ensue

Overreach (Success + Desperation 1s): - Choose: Keep success + gain Danger = number of 1s - Or: Enter Despair (reject success)

Automatic Despair (Failure + Desperation 1s): - Automatically enter Despair - Drive lost - Must use /redemption after completing Redemption

docs.title: Advanced Usage
docs.text:
With Danger: Your Danger rating adds to difficulty: 

Character Danger: 3
/roll pool:7 difficulty:2

Effective difficulty: 2 + 3 = 5
(Herald doesn't auto-add, adjust manually)

With Specialties: Add +2 dice when specialty applies: 

Firearms 3 + Specialty "Pistols" = 5 dice (when using pistols)
/roll pool:5 difficulty:2 comment:Shooting with my specialty

Contested Rolls: Both sides roll separately, compare successes: 

Hunter: /roll pool:6 difficulty:0 comment:Sneaking
Storyteller rolls guard separately
Higher successes wins

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Always add comments - Helps track what you're rolling
  • Check Desperation - Use /desperation action:view first
  • Calculate pools - Attribute + Skill + Modifiers
  • Watch for Danger - High Danger = much harder rolls
  • Save Desperation - Only use when you must succeed

docs.title: /danger
docs.text: View or manage your character's Danger rating.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: /danger action:ACTION [amount:X]

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• action (required) - view, set, add, subtract, reset
  • amount (optional) - Amount for set/add/subtract actions

docs.title: Actions
docs.text:
View Danger: 

/danger action:view
Shows current Danger rating and visual bar.

Set Danger: 

/danger action:set amount:5
Sets Danger to exact value (0-10).

Add Danger: 

/danger action:add amount:2
Increases Danger by amount (from Overreach).

Subtract Danger: 

/danger action:subtract amount:1
Decreases Danger by amount (resolving threats).

Reset Danger: 

/danger action:reset
Sets Danger to 0 (after resolving major threats).

docs.title: What is Danger?
docs.text: Danger (0-10) represents supernatural threats building around you: - Gained through Overreach (accepting Desperation 1s) - Adds to difficulty of all rolls - Represents monsters closing in - Should be resolved through story

docs.title: Danger Effects
docs.text:
Mechanical: - Adds to difficulty on all rolls - Danger 3 + Difficulty 2 = Effective Difficulty 5

Narrative: - Monsters are tracking you - Supernatural forces converging - Time running out - Threats escalating

High Danger (7+): - All tasks extremely difficult - Major story consequences imminent - Should be addressed urgently - Storyteller may force confrontation

docs.title: Visual Display
docs.text:
Danger: 🟥🟥🟥🟥🟥▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️ 5/10
- 🟥 Filled squares (current Danger) - ▪️ Empty squares (remaining capacity)

docs.title: Managing Danger
docs.text:
Gaining Danger: 1. Roll with Desperation 2. Get success + Desperation 1s 3. Choose Overreach over Despair 4. Danger increases by number of 1s

Reducing Danger: 1. Confront the threat directly 2. Resolve supernatural situation 3. Complete story arc 4. Storyteller discretion

Typical Reset Points: - After defeating major enemy - Resolving the hunt - End of story arc - Escaping to safety

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
After Overreach: 

(Rolled success with 3 Desperation 1s, accepted Overreach)
/danger action:add amount:3
Danger increased from 2 to 5

After Resolving Threat: 

(Destroyed the vampire's haven, broke its hold)
/danger action:reset
Danger reduced to 0

Partial Resolution: 

(Escaped the area but threat remains)
/danger action:subtract amount:2
Danger decreased from 5 to 3

docs.title: Strategy
docs.text:
Low Danger (0-3): - Safe to use Desperation - Minor threats manageable - Continue hunting normally

Moderate Danger (4-6): - Be cautious with Desperation - Threats building up - Consider addressing soon

High Danger (7-9): - Avoid Desperation if possible - Major threats imminent - Must resolve soon

Critical Danger (10): - Maximum threat level - All rolls extremely difficult - Immediate story confrontation - Resolution critical

docs.text:
Standard Roll: 

1. Calculate pool (Attribute + Skill + Modifiers)

docs.title: Step 3: Review Permissions
docs.text: Herald requests the following permissions:

docs.title: Required Permissions
docs.text:
• Send Messages - Respond to commands and send results
  • Embed Links - Display character sheets and dice results in formatted embeds
  • Use Slash Commands - Access to Discord's slash command system (automatic)

docs.title: Recommended Permissions
docs.text:
• Use External Emoji - Display custom dice emojis for better-looking rolls
  • Without this, Herald uses text-based dice results instead

docs.title: Optional Permissions
docs.text: None! Herald doesn't need any elevated permissions like managing roles, channels, or messages.

docs.title: Step 4: Authorize
docs.text:
Click Authorize to complete the installation.

Herald will join your server and be ready to use immediately!

docs.title: Check if Herald is Online
docs.text:
1. Look for Herald in your server's member list
  2. Herald should show as online (green status)
  3. If offline, Herald may be restarting or experiencing issues

docs.title: Test a Command
docs.text:
Try a simple command to verify Herald is working:

/help

If Herald responds with the help menu, everything is working correctly!

docs.title: Herald Isn't Responding
docs.text:
Check slash command permissions:

  1. Go to Server Settings → Integrations → Herald
  2. Ensure slash commands are enabled
  3. Check that the @everyone role (or your role) has Use Application Commands permission

Check channel permissions:

  1. Herald needs permission to view and send messages in channels where commands are used
  2. Right-click the channel → Edit Channel → Permissions
  3. Ensure Herald's role has Send Messages and View Channel enabled

docs.title: Dice Emojis Not Showing
docs.text:
Herald uses custom emojis to display dice results. If you see text instead of emoji:

Option 1: Enable External Emoji Permission 1. Give Herald the Use External Emoji permission

Option 2: Use Text Mode - Herald automatically falls back to text-based results - No configuration needed!

docs.title: Commands Not Appearing
docs.text:
If slash commands don't appear when you type /:

  1. Wait a few minutes - Discord can take time to sync commands
  2. Try restarting your Discord client
  3. Check that Herald has the Use Application Commands permission
  4. Try using the command anyway by typing it fully: /help

  2. Pin a message with common commands or the bot invite link

  • Players - Active players in your games
  • Spectators - People who can view but not roll

Herald doesn't require special roles, but they can help organize your server!

docs.title: Maximizing Dice Pools
docs.text:
The 8-Dice Threshold: - 8+ dice pools have high success rates - Target: Primary attribute 4 + Primary skill 4 = 8 dice - Secondary pools: 5-7 dice - Tertiary pools: 3-4 dice acceptable

Optimization path:

Starting (0 XP): - Dexterity 4, Firearms 4 = 8 dice (shooting) - Intelligence 3, Investigation 3 = 6 dice (clues) - Manipulation 2, Persuasion 2 = 4 dice (social)

Early (20 XP): - Raise Firearms to 5 = 9 dice shooting (10 XP) - Add 2 specialties (6 XP) - Save 4 XP

Mid (50 XP): - Raise Dexterity to 5 = 10 dice shooting (20 XP) - Raise Investigation to 4 = 7 dice investigating (8 XP) - Buy second Edge (15 XP) - Remaining: 7 XP

docs.title: Attribute Priority
docs.text:
Combat character: 1. Dexterity 4-5 (hit targets) 2. Stamina 3-4 (survive hits) 3. Wits 3 (initiative) 4. Composure/Resolve 2-3 each (Willpower 4-6)

Social character: 1. Charisma or Manipulation 4-5 (influence) 2. Composure 3-4 (resist pressure) 3. Wits or Intelligence 3 (read situations) 4. Dexterity 2 (minimum combat capability)

Investigation character: 1. Intelligence 4-5 (analyze) 2. Wits 4 (notice and act fast) 3. Composure 3 (Willpower for mental resistance) 4. Dexterity 3 (basic combat)

docs.title: Skill Priority
docs.text:
Essential skills (everyone): - Awareness 3 - Spot threats and clues - Athletics 2 - Dodge and maneuver - One combat skill 3-4 - Survive fights

Combat specialists: - Firearms 4-5 or Melee 4-5 - Athletics 3 - Dodge - Stealth 2-3 - Positioning

Social specialists: - Persuasion or Intimidation 4-5 - Insight 3 - Read people - Subterfuge 3 - Deception

Investigation specialists: - Investigation 4-5 - Occult 3-4 - Awareness 4

docs.title: Specialty Placement
docs.text:
Priority order: 1. Primary attack skill (Firearms, Melee, Brawl) 2. Primary investigation skill (Investigation, Occult, Awareness) 3. Primary social skill (Persuasion, Subterfuge, Insight)

Avoid: - Specialties on skills with only 1 dot - Specialties too broad to apply often - Duplicate specialty types

docs.title: Derived Stats Optimization
docs.text:
Health = Stamina + 3: - Minimum: 5 (Stamina 2) - Recommended: 6 (Stamina 3) - Optimal: 7+ (Stamina 4-5)

Willpower = Composure + Resolve: - Minimum: 4 (2 + 2) - Recommended: 5 (3 + 2 or 2 + 3) - Optimal: 6+ (3 + 3 or 4 + 2)

docs.title: Combat Synergies
docs.text:
Arsenal + Avenger: - Heavy armament - Vengeance-driven warrior - Always armed and ready - Best skills: Firearms 5, Athletics 3, Intimidation 3

Fleet + Defender: - Mobile protector - Rapid response - Superior positioning - Best skills: Melee 4, Athletics 4, Awareness 3

Senses + Any combat Creed: - Never surprised - Enhanced awareness in fights - Spot ambushes - Best skills: Awareness 5, Firearms 4, Investigation 3

Fame + Redeemer: - Public influence - Leverage celebrity - Redemption through visibility - Best skills: Persuasion 5, Performance 4, Leadership 3

Status + Zealot: - Institutional authority - Command structure - Organized crusade - Best skills: Leadership 4, Intimidation 4, Politics 3

docs.title: Investigation Synergies
docs.text:
Library + Innocent: - Research-driven discovery - Knowledge accumulation - Understanding the supernatural - Best skills: Investigation 5, Academics 4, Occult 4

Third Eye + Any Creed: - See supernatural truth - Identify threats instantly - Mystical perception - Best skills: Awareness 4, Occult 4, Investigation 3

Global Access + Defender: - Information network - Track threats globally - Protect proactively - Best skills: Investigation 4, Technology 4, Awareness 3

docs.title: Support Synergies
docs.text:
Martyr + Defender: - Protect through sacrifice - Tank damage for allies - Ultimate guardian - Best skills: Medicine 4, Athletics 3, Composure 4

Inspire + Any combat Creed: - Leadership in battle - Buff allies - Force multiplier - Best skills: Leadership 5, Firearms 4, Charisma 4

Benediction + Redeemer: - Divine healing - Spiritual protection - Redemptive power - Best skills: Medicine 4, Persuasion 3, Composure 4

docs.text:
Arsenal + Fleet: - Mobile heavy weapons platform - Hit-and-run tactics - Superior firepower + positioning

Contacts + Library: - Information dominance - Human and textual sources - Know everything

Senses + Third Eye: - Ultimate perception - See both mundane and supernatural - Nothing escapes notice

Inspire + Martyr: - Ultimate support - Buff and protect team - Battlefield leadership

docs.title: When to Use Desperation
docs.text:
Always use when: - Character death is imminent - Ally is dying - Mission-critical roll (one chance) - Final confrontation with major threat

Usually use when: - Danger is low (0-3) - Success is very important - Failure has severe consequences - Storyteller hints it's needed

Rarely use when: - Danger is high (7-10) - Roll is not critical - Other options exist - You're already in Despair

Never use when: - Routine tasks - Low-stakes situations - You can afford to fail - Risk of Despair > reward

docs.title: Danger Management
docs.text:
Keep Danger low: - Rest and downtime (-1 per session) - Complete Redemption paths - Avoid unnecessary Desperation use - Ask Storyteller for Danger reduction opportunities

Monitor thresholds: - 0-3: Safe to use Desperation - 4-6: Caution advised - 7-9: High risk - 10: Extreme danger

Danger reduction tactics: - Narrative downtime between arcs - Completing personal storylines - Redemption paths - Storyteller rewards

docs.title: Overreach Decisions
docs.text:
When you Overreach (Success + Desperation 1s):

Choose success when: - You can handle the Danger increase - Success is worth the cost - You're at low Danger already - Mission success > personal safety

Choose Despair when: - Danger is already high (8+) - Failure advances character story - Redemption path is interesting - You want dramatic character moment

Example: 

Danger 2, roll 6 successes, 2 Desperation 1s
Choose: Keep 6 successes + gain Danger 2 (total Danger 4)
Reason: Danger 4 is still safe, success is critical

docs.title: Despair Strategy
docs.text:
Embrace Despair narratively: - Don't avoid it out of fear - It's a feature, not a punishment - Creates great character moments - Drives personal stories

Plan Redemption: - Work with Storyteller - Tie to your Drive - Make it meaningful - Use it to advance character arc

Redemption examples:

Vengeance Drive in Despair: - Redemption: Hunt down and hurt your quarry - Approach: 1-2 session mini-arc - Completion: Dramatic confrontation

Virtue Drive in Despair: - Redemption: Uphold morals despite darkness - Approach: Moral dilemma, choose right path - Completion: Resist temptation

docs.title: Action Economy
docs.text: Maximize effectiveness per turn: - Attack with highest pool - Position for next turn - Coordinate with allies - Don't waste actions on low-probability moves

docs.title: Positioning
docs.text:
Use environment: - Cover: Increases difficulty to hit you - High ground: Bonus to attack - Choke points: Limit enemy movement - Escape routes: Always have one

Describe tactics: - "I take cover behind the car" = +1 difficulty to hit you - "I flank while they're distracted" = -1 difficulty to hit - "I climb to the roof" = high ground advantage

docs.title: Focus Fire
docs.text:
Concentrate attacks: - All Hunters attack one target - Eliminate threats quickly - Reduces enemy action economy - Protects wounded allies

Priority targets: 1. Healers/support - Eliminate first 2. High damage dealers - Remove threats 3. Weak enemies - Easy kills 4. Leaders - Disrupt coordination

docs.title: Desperation in Combat
docs.text:
Critical moments: 

/roll pool:8 difficulty:4 desperate:true comment:Killing blow on vampire lord

Don't waste on: - Minions - Early fight rounds - When allies can succeed - If you're at high Danger

docs.title: Defensive Tactics
docs.text:
Dodge vs. Tank: - Dodge: Dexterity + Athletics (avoid damage) - Tank: Stamina + Resolve (absorb damage) - High Dex = dodge - High Stamina = tank

When to retreat: - Health below 3 - Willpower depleted - Allies down - Outnumbered 3-to-1 or more

docs.title: Systematic Searching
docs.text:
Layer your investigation:

Layer 1: Quick scan 

/roll pool:5 difficulty:2 comment:Initial look around
(Wits + Awareness)

Layer 2: Detailed search 

/roll pool:7 difficulty:2 comment:Thorough investigation
(Intelligence + Investigation)

Layer 3: Specialist knowledge 

/roll pool:6 difficulty:3 comment:Occult analysis
(Intelligence + Occult)

Layer 4: Follow up - Track leads from previous rolls - Interview witnesses - Research findings

docs.title: Information Gathering
docs.text: Diverse sources: - Physical evidence: Investigation rolls - Witnesses: Social rolls (Persuasion, Intimidation) - Research: Academics, Occult rolls - Networks: Use Contacts Edge - Technology: Technology skill for hacking/research

docs.title: Research Tactics
docs.text:
Library Edge optimization: - Focus on obscure knowledge - Leverage +2 dice on research - Cross-reference sources - Find patterns

Occult research: - Identify creature types - Find weaknesses - Understand rituals - Prevent supernatural events

docs.title: Reading People
docs.text:
Always open with Insight: 

/roll pool:5 difficulty:2 comment:Reading their demeanor

Learn: - Emotional state - Motivations - Hidden agendas - Weaknesses

docs.title: Persuasion vs. Intimidation
docs.text:
Use Persuasion when: - Target is neutral or friendly - You need cooperation - Long-term relationship matters - Subtlety is required

Use Intimidation when: - Target is hostile - Quick compliance needed - Relationship doesn't matter - Show of force is appropriate

docs.title: Multi-Stage Social Encounters
docs.text:
Stage 1: Establish rapport 

/roll pool:6 difficulty:2 comment:Building trust
(Charisma + Persuasion)

Stage 2: Probe for information 

/roll pool:5 difficulty:2 comment:Subtle questioning
(Manipulation + Subterfuge)

Stage 3: Read response 

/roll pool:5 difficulty:3 comment:Detecting lies
(Wits + Insight)

Stage 4: Close the deal 

/roll pool:7 difficulty:3 comment:Securing cooperation
(Manipulation + Persuasion)

docs.title: Using Fame and Status
docs.text:
Fame tactics: - Leverage public recognition - Manipulate media - Access exclusive areas - Influence public opinion

Status tactics: - Exercise authority - Command subordinates - Bypass bureaucracy - Intimidate through position

docs.title: The Specialist
docs.text:
Philosophy: Master one thing completely

Example: Sniper - Dexterity 5, Firearms 5 = 10 dice - Specialties: Firearms (Rifles), Firearms (Long Range), Awareness (Spotting) - Edge: Arsenal (always have perfect weapon) - Role: Long-range elimination

Strengths: - Unmatched at primary role - Reliable specialist

Weaknesses: - Vulnerable outside specialty - Party dependent

docs.title: The Generalist
docs.text:
Philosophy: Contribute to everything

Example: Jack-of-All-Trades - Balanced attributes (3s and 2s) - Many skills at 2-3 - Edge: Scrounger or Fleet - Role: Fill gaps, backup everyone

Strengths: - Adaptable - Never useless

Weaknesses: - Never best at anything - Slower progression

docs.title: The Hybrid
docs.text:
Philosophy: Excel at two areas

Example: Combat Investigator - Dexterity 4, Intelligence 4 - Firearms 4, Investigation 4 - Edge: Senses - Role: Investigate, then eliminate

Strengths: - Versatile in two areas - Valuable in most scenes

Weaknesses: - Split XP investment - Slower mastery

docs.title: The Support
docs.text:
Philosophy: Make others better

Example: Team Leader - Charisma 5, Composure 4 - Leadership 5, Medicine 3, Inspire Edge - Role: Buff allies, heal, coordinate

Strengths: - Force multiplier - Team survivability

Weaknesses: - Low personal power - Depends on team

docs.title: XP Priorities
docs.text:
0-20 XP: 1. Raise primary skill to 4 (8 XP) 2. Buy 2-3 specialties (6-9 XP) 3. Save remainder

21-50 XP: 1. Raise primary attribute to 5 (20 XP) 2. Raise primary skill to 5 (10 XP) 3. Buy second Edge (15-20 XP)

51-100 XP: 1. Raise secondary attributes to 4 (12-16 XP each) 2. Raise secondary skills to 4 (8 XP each) 3. Buy Perks (5-10 XP each)

docs.title: Dice Pool Targets
docs.text:
• Primary: 8-10 dice
  • Secondary: 5-7 dice
  • Tertiary: 3-4 dice
  • Minimum: 3 dice (don't roll less)

docs.title: Stat Minimums
docs.text:
• Health: 5+ (Stamina 2+)
  • Willpower: 4+ (Composure + Resolve = 4+)
  • Primary attribute: 4 minimum
  • Primary skill: 4 minimum
  • Awareness: 2 minimum
  • Combat skill: 2 minimum

docs.title: Basic Dice Rolling
docs.text: Learn how to roll dice with Herald using H5E mechanics.

docs.title: Rolling Methods
docs.text: Herald offers three ways to roll dice:

docs.title: 1. Manual Roll (/roll)
docs.text:
Roll dice manually without a character:

/roll attribute:3 skill:2 difficulty:2

Best for: - Quick rolls - Rolling for NPCs - Testing dice mechanics - When you don't have a character

docs.title: 2. Character Roll (/roll_char)
docs.text:
Roll using your character's stats:

/roll_char character:Raven attribute:Dexterity skill:Firearms difficulty:2

Best for: - Regular play - Character actions - When you want stat tracking - Automatic Edge/Desperation

docs.title: 3. Simple Roll (/simple)
docs.text:
Basic dice pool without H5E mechanics:

/simple pool:5

Best for: - Non-H5E rolling - Pure dice pools - Quick tests

docs.title: Dice Pool
docs.text:
Your dice pool = Attribute + Skill + Modifiers + Edge

Dexterity 4 + Firearms 3 + Edge 2 = 9 dice

docs.title: Successes
docs.text:
• 6-9 = Success (1 success)
  • 10 = Critical (2 successes)
  • 1-5 = Failure (no success)

docs.title: Difficulty
docs.text:
Difficulty is the target number of successes you need:

Difficulty Description 0 Automatic (no roll needed) 1 Simple task 2 Standard challenge 3 Hard task 4 Extreme challenge 5 Nearly impossible 6+ Legendary feat

docs.title: Margin
docs.text:
Margin = Total Successes - Difficulty

  • Margin 0+ = Success
  • Margin below 0 = Failure
  • Higher margin = Better success

docs.title: Simple Attack Roll
docs.text:
/roll_char character:Raven attribute:Dexterity skill:Firearms difficulty:2

Herald shows: - Pool calculation (Dexterity 4 + Firearms 3 = 7 dice) - Dice results with emojis - Total successes - Whether you met the difficulty - Margin of success

docs.title: Investigation Check
docs.text: /roll_char character:Raven attribute:Wits skill:Investigation difficulty:3

docs.title: Stealth Action
docs.text: /roll_char character:Raven attribute:Dexterity skill:Stealth difficulty:2

docs.title: Edge Dice
docs.text: Edge adds dice to your pool:

docs.title: Automatic Edge
docs.text:
Herald automatically adds your character's Edge rating:

/roll_char character:Raven attribute:Strength skill:Brawl

# Herald adds Raven's Edge (2) automatically
# Pool = Strength 2 + Brawl 2 + Edge 2 = 6 dice

docs.title: Override Edge
docs.text:
Override your character's Edge for this roll:

/roll_char character:Raven attribute:Strength skill:Brawl edge:4

# Uses Edge 4 instead of Raven's normal Edge 2

docs.title: No Edge
docs.text:
Roll without Edge:

/roll_char character:Raven attribute:Strength skill:Brawl edge:0

docs.title: Desperation Dice
docs.text: Desperation dice are special - they can cause messy criticals!

docs.title: When Desperation Triggers
docs.text:
Herald uses your character's Desperation rating to determine when to roll Desperation dice:

/roll_char character:Raven attribute:Wits skill:Awareness desperation:True

docs.title: Messy Criticals
docs.text:
If Desperation dice roll 10s:

  • You get the successes
  • BUT something goes wrong
  • Storyteller determines the complication

Messy Critical

When you see "Messy Critical!" in your roll result, you succeeded but at a cost. The Storyteller will describe what went wrong.

docs.title: Modifiers
docs.text: Add or subtract dice from your pool:

docs.title: Add Dice
docs.text:
/roll_char character:Raven attribute:Dexterity skill:Stealth modifier:2

Good for: - Favorable circumstances - Equipment bonuses - Help from allies - Using specialties (Herald does this automatically!)

docs.title: Subtract Dice
docs.text:
/roll_char character:Raven attribute:Strength skill:Athletics modifier:-2

Good for: - Penalties - Poor conditions - Injuries - Distractions

docs.title: Specialties
docs.text: When your specialty applies, Herald automatically adds +1 die!

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Character has: Firearms (Pistols)

/roll_char character:Raven attribute:Dexterity skill:Firearms

# If using a pistol, Herald adds +1 automatically
# Storyteller confirms if specialty applies

Specialty Bonus

Talk to your Storyteller about when specialties apply. Herald tracks them but relies on you to use the right skill!

docs.title: Reading Roll Results
docs.text: Herald displays rolls in Inconnu style:

docs.title: Result Display
docs.text:
═══════════════════════════════
Raven
═══════════════════════════════

3 successes

Dexterity + Firearms = 7 dice

What this means:

  • Character name - Who rolled
  • Successes - How many you got (10=crit, 6-9=success)
  • Pool - What you rolled
  • Dice - Individual results
  • Margin - How much you beat the difficulty by

docs.title: Success Types
docs.text: Result Description Critical! Double 10s - exceptional success X successes Standard success Failure Didn't meet difficulty Messy Critical! Success from Desperation 10s - with complication

Both parties roll, highest successes wins:

# Compare totals

/roll_char character:Raven attribute:Intelligence skill:Investigation

docs.title: Character Concept
docs.text: Before entering any Herald commands, develop your character's concept.

docs.title: The Three Questions
docs.text:
1. Who are you? - Name and background - Profession before Hunting - Personality and motivations

2. Why do you Hunt? - What revealed the truth to you? - What keeps you Hunting despite the danger? - What's your ultimate goal?

3. How do you Hunt? - Combat specialist or support? - Social manipulator or investigator? - Lone wolf or team player?

docs.title: Concept Examples
docs.text:
The Detective - Former police officer who discovered vampires - Hunts to protect the innocent - Investigative and tactical approach

The Priest - Catholic priest who witnessed demonic possession - Hunts to redeem the corrupted - Spiritual and compassionate approach

The Soldier - Special forces veteran who lost their squad to werewolves - Hunts for vengeance - Direct combat approach

The Student - College student who researched the wrong occult tome - Hunts out of curiosity and responsibility - Research and knowledge-based approach

The Doctor - ER surgeon who treated supernatural injuries - Hunts to save lives - Medical and support approach

docs.title: Attribute Allocation
docs.text: You distribute 9 dots across 9 attributes (all start at 1).

docs.title: Distribution Patterns
docs.text:
Specialist (7/4/2): - One category at 4 dots (7 total after base 1s) - One category at 3 dots (6 total) - One category at 2 dots (5 total) - Best for focused characters

Generalist (5/5/3): - Two categories at 4 dots each - One category at 1 dot - Best for versatile characters

Balanced (5/4/4): - Distributed more evenly - No major weaknesses - Best for uncertain roles

docs.title: Attribute Categories
docs.text:
Physical (Strength, Dexterity, Stamina): - Strength - Melee damage, intimidation, athletics - Dexterity - Firearms, driving, stealth, initiative - Stamina - Health, endurance, resisting damage

Social (Charisma, Manipulation, Composure): - Charisma - Leadership, persuasion, first impressions - Manipulation - Deception, subterfuge, coercion - Composure - Willpower, staying calm, resisting social pressure

Mental (Intelligence, Wits, Resolve): - Intelligence - Research, investigation, knowledge - Wits - Awareness, quick thinking, initiative - Resolve - Willpower, determination, mental resistance

docs.title: Strategic Priorities
docs.text:
Combat Character: - Dexterity 3-4 (firearms accuracy) - Stamina 3-4 (survive longer) - Wits 2-3 (better initiative)

Social Character: - Charisma or Manipulation 3-4 (influence) - Composure 3-4 (resist pressure) - Intelligence 2-3 (read situations)

Investigation Character: - Intelligence 3-4 (analyze clues) - Wits 3-4 (notice details) - Composure 2-3 (stay focused)

docs.title: Skill Categories
docs.text:
Physical Skills: - Athletics - Running, climbing, dodging, jumping - Brawl - Unarmed combat, grappling - Craft - Building, repairing, creating - Driving - Vehicles, chases, maneuvering - Firearms - Guns, ranged combat - Larceny - Lockpicking, security systems - Melee - Armed close combat - Stealth - Hiding, sneaking, ambushing - Survival - Tracking, outdoors, first aid

docs.title: Specialty Planning
docs.text: You get 3 specialties to start.

docs.title: How Specialties Work
docs.text:
When you use a specialty: 1. Roll your dice pool normally 2. Count successes as usual 3. If you succeed, reroll any 1s once 4. Add any new successes from rerolled dice

Example: - Roll Firearms 3 + Dexterity 3 = 6 dice - Result: [7][4][1][1][9][3] = 3 successes - Specialty: Firearms (Pistols) applies - Reroll the two 1s: [6][2] = 1 additional success - Final: 4 successes total

docs.title: Specialty Rules
docs.text:
Requirements: - Skill must have 1+ dots - Can have multiple specialties per skill - Max specialties per skill = skill dots

Best Practices: - Put specialties on your most-used skills - Narrow focus increases applicability - Coordinate with your concept

docs.title: Creed and Drive
docs.text: Your Creed and Drive define who you are as a Hunter.

docs.title: The Five Creeds
docs.text:
Defender 🛡️ - Philosophy: Protect the innocent from supernatural harm - Fields: Investigation, protection, community defense - Best For: Guardians, protectors, police officers - Drives: Virtue, Ambition, Competition

Innocent 🤔 - Philosophy: Stumbled into the truth, learning as you go - Fields: Adaptation, survival, discovery - Best For: Reluctant heroes, ordinary people thrust into danger - Drives: Curiosity, Vice, Rebellion

Redeemer 🕊️ - Philosophy: Save the corrupted, redeem the fallen - Fields: Compassion, understanding, mercy - Best For: Priests, counselors, idealists - Drives: Virtue, Ambition, Desire

Avenger ⚔️ - Philosophy: Punish the guilty, destroy the wicked - Fields: Justice, retribution, judgment - Best For: Soldiers, vigilantes, survivors - Drives: Vengeance, Competition, Rebellion

Zealot 🔥 - Philosophy: Eradicate all supernatural darkness - Fields: Extremism, purification, total war - Best For: Fanatics, extremists, true believers - Drives: Ambition, Vengeance, Virtue

docs.title: The Seven Drives
docs.text: Ambition - Achieve greatness through the Hunt Competition - Prove yourself the best Hunter Curiosity - Uncover the truth about the supernatural Desire - Fulfill a specific want or need Rebellion - Reject authority and societal norms Vengeance - Hurt those who hurt you or others Vice - Indulge in pleasures or addictions Virtue - Uphold moral principles and ethics

docs.title: Creed + Drive Combinations
docs.text:
Defender + Virtue: "I protect because it's right." - Classic heroic guardian - Strong moral compass - Self-sacrificing

Avenger + Vengeance: "They killed my family. I'll kill them all." - Dark vigilante - Driven by loss - Brutal efficiency

Innocent + Curiosity: "I need to understand what's happening." - Reluctant investigator - Learning the truth - Growth-focused

Redeemer + Desire: "I want to save my sister from the vampires." - Personal mission - Compassionate approach - Specific goal

Zealot + Ambition: "I'll lead the crusade against darkness." - Fanatical leader - Grand vision - Uncompromising

docs.text:
/creed creed:Defender
/drive drive:Virtue

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
Don't spread too thin: - ❌ Many skills at 1 dot - ✅ Few skills at 3-4 dots

Don't neglect awareness: - ❌ Awareness 0 - ✅ Awareness 2-3 minimum

Don't forget combat: - ❌ No combat skills - ✅ At least Firearms 2 or Brawl 2

Don't ignore Willpower: - ❌ Composure 1, Resolve 1 (Willpower 2) - ✅ At least one at 2-3 (Willpower 4-5)

docs.title: Optimization Strategies
docs.text:
Maximize primary pools: - Identify your character's main role - Get primary attribute + skill = 6-8 dice - Example: Dexterity 4 + Firearms 4 = 8 dice

Ensure minimums: - Health 5+ (Stamina 2+) - Willpower 4+ (Composure + Resolve = 4+) - Awareness 2+ - One combat skill 2+

Plan progression: - Know what you'll raise first - Attributes are expensive (new × 4 XP) - Skills are cheaper (new × 2 XP) - Specialties are cheap (3 XP each)

Coordinate with team: - Don't duplicate roles - Cover each other's weaknesses - Share information and resources

docs.title: Power Gaming Considerations
docs.text:
Maximum combat effectiveness: - Dexterity 4, Stamina 3 minimum - Firearms 4 or Melee 4 - Athletics 3 - Arsenal or Fleet Edge

Maximum social influence: - Charisma or Manipulation 4 - Persuasion 4 or Subterfuge 4 - Insight 3 - Contacts, Fame, or Status Edge

docs.title: Creating Your First Character
docs.text: Let's create your first Hunter character step-by-step!

docs.title: The Quick Way
docs.text:
Want to jump right in? Use this single command:

/create name:Raven

Done! Herald creates a basic character with: - All attributes set to 1 - All skills set to 0 - Default Health (3) and Willpower (3) - No Edge or Desperation

You can customize everything later!

docs.title: The Detailed Way
docs.text:
Want more control from the start? Include attributes in your creation:

/create name:Raven strength:2 dexterity:4 stamina:3 charisma:3 manipulation:2 composure:3 intelligence:3 wits:3 resolve:2

Attribute Distribution

In H5E, new Hunters typically have:

  • Total of 12 dots across all 9 attributes
  • No attribute higher than 5
  • Minimum of 1 in each attribute (Herald's default)

docs.title: 1. Choose a Name
docs.text:
Pick a name for your Hunter. This is what you'll use to reference them in commands:

/create name:Raven

Character Names

  • Use quotes for multi-word names: name:"Sarah Connor"
  • Names are case-insensitive for commands
  • Each character name must be unique to you

docs.title: 2. Set Attributes
docs.text: Herald uses the 9 core H5E attributes:

docs.title: Physical
docs.text:
• Strength - Raw physical power
  • Dexterity - Agility and coordination
  • Stamina - Endurance and toughness

docs.title: Social
docs.text:
• Charisma - Charm and force of personality
  • Manipulation - Subtlety and persuasion
  • Composure - Self-control and poise

docs.title: Mental
docs.text:
• Intelligence - Reasoning and memory
  • Wits - Quick thinking and awareness
  • Resolve - Determination and focus

Example: 

/create name:Raven strength:2 dexterity:4 stamina:3 charisma:3 manipulation:2 composure:3 intelligence:3 wits:3 resolve:2

docs.title: 3. View Your Character
docs.text:
Check out your new character:

/sheet character:Raven

Herald displays your complete character sheet with: - All attributes - Derived stats (Health, Willpower) - Empty skills (ready to fill in) - Hunter traits (Creed, Edge, etc.)

docs.title: Setting Up Skills
docs.text: Now let's add skills to your character!

docs.title: Option 1: Skill Template (Fastest)
docs.text:
Apply a pre-built skill distribution:

/skill_template character:Raven template:Balanced

Available Templates:

  • Balanced (7/5/3/1) - Well-rounded Hunter
  • 1 skill at 4 dots
  • 3 skills at 3 dots
  • 4 skills at 2 dots

  • 4 skills at 1 dot

  • Specialist (9/5/1/0) - Focused expert

  • 1 skill at 5 dots
  • 2 skills at 4 dots
  • 3 skills at 3 dots

  • 3 skills at 2 dots

  • Jack-of-all-trades (5/5/5/0) - Broad competence

  • 8 skills at 2 dots
  • 4 skills at 1 dot

Skill Points

H5E characters typically start with 11 skill dots in their primary category, 7 in secondary, and 4 in tertiary.

docs.title: Option 2: Individual Skills
docs.text:
Set skills one at a time for complete control:

/skill_set character:Raven skill:Firearms dots:3
/skill_set character:Raven skill:Stealth dots:4
/skill_set character:Raven skill:Investigation dots:2

docs.title: Option 3: Bulk Setting
docs.text:
Set multiple skills at once:

/skill_bulk character:Raven skill1:Firearms dots1:3 skill2:Stealth dots2:4 skill3:Investigation dots3:2

docs.title: Adding Specialties
docs.text:
Give your character specialties for bonus dice in specific situations:

/specialty character:Raven skill:Firearms specialty:Pistols
/specialty character:Raven skill:Stealth specialty:Urban

When you roll with a specialty, you get +1 die if the situation matches!

docs.title: Choose Your Creed
docs.text:
Every Hunter has a Creed that defines their philosophy:

/creed character:Raven creed:Avenger

Available Creeds: - Avenger - Defender - Innocent - Judge - Martyr - Redeemer - Visionary

docs.title: Set Your Drives
docs.text:
Define what motivates your Hunter:

# Long-term goal
/ambition character:Raven ambition:"Rid the city of vampires"

# Short-term goal  
/desire character:Raven desire:"Find the creature that killed my sister"

# Hunting motivation
/drive character:Raven drive:"Protect the innocent from supernatural predators"

docs.title: Set Edge
docs.text:
Edge represents supernatural insight and power:

/edge character:Raven edge:2

Edge Rating

Most starting Hunters have Edge 1-3. Edge adds dice to rolls and has special properties.

docs.title: Add Equipment
docs.text:
Track your Hunter's gear:

/equipment character:Raven equipment:"Glock 17, tactical vest, flashlight, silver knife, rosary"

docs.title: Add Notes
docs.text:
Keep notes about your character:

/notes character:Raven notes:"Former detective. Sister killed by vampire. Joined the hunt 6 months ago. Has a cat named Midnight."

docs.title: Your Character is Ready!
docs.text: 🎉 Congratulations! You now have a complete Hunter character.

docs.title: Quick Test Roll
docs.text:
Try rolling some dice with your new character:

/roll_char character:Raven attribute:Dexterity skill:Firearms difficulty:2

Herald will: 1. Look up Raven's Dexterity and Firearms ratings 2. Roll the combined pool 3. Check for successes against difficulty 2 4. Display clean, readable results

Welcome to Herald, your complete Hunter: The Reckoning 5th Edition companion for Discord.

This guide walks you through your first character and your first game session. In 10 minutes, you'll be ready to Hunt.

docs.title: Quick Start: Your First 5 Minutes
docs.text: Let's create a character and make your first roll.

docs.title: 1. Create Your Character
docs.text:
Open Discord and type:

/create name:Alex Hunter

Herald creates a basic character with: - All attributes at 1 (minimum) - No skills yet - Default Health (4) and Willpower (2) - Zero Desperation

You see: 

✅ Character created: Alex Hunter
Use /sheet to view your character
Use /character to switch characters

docs.title: 2. View Your Character Sheet
docs.text:
/sheet

Herald displays your complete character sheet: - Attributes (all 1s for now) - Skills (none yet) - Health (4) and Willpower (2) - Desperation (0) - No Edges or Perks yet

docs.title: 3. Make Your First Roll
docs.text:
Let's test your luck:

/roll pool:5 difficulty:2 comment:My first roll!

What happens: - Herald rolls 5 ten-sided dice - Counts successes (6+ on each die) - Compares to difficulty (2 successes needed) - Displays the result with visual dice

You might see: 

🎲 Alex Hunter - My first roll!
Pool: 5 | Difficulty: 2

Dice: [7] [3] [9] [2] [6]
Successes: 3 (7, 9, 6)

✅ SUCCESS (3 successes, needed 2)
Margin: 1

Congratulations! You just made your first H5E roll.

docs.title: Your First Real Character
docs.text: Now let's build a proper Hunter.

docs.title: Step 1: Plan Your Character
docs.text:
Before touching Herald, answer these questions:

Who are you? - Name and background - Why do you Hunt? - What's your specialty?

What's your Creed? - Defender - Protect the innocent - Innocent - Stumbled into the truth - Redeemer - Save the monsters - Avenger - Punish the guilty - Zealot - Destroy all darkness

What's your Drive? - Ambition, Competition, Curiosity, Rebellion, Vengeance, Vice, Virtue

Example Concept: "Detective Maria Santos, Defender, Drive: Justice (Virtue). She protects her neighborhood from supernatural threats."

docs.title: Step 2: Set Your Attributes
docs.text:
You have 9 dots to distribute across 9 attributes (minimum 1 each):

Prioritize one category: - Physical (Strength, Dexterity, Stamina): 4 dots - Social (Charisma, Manipulation, Composure): 3 dots - Mental (Intelligence, Wits, Resolve): 2 dots

Detective Maria Santos example: 

/attributes attribute:Strength dots:2
/attributes attribute:Dexterity dots:3
/attributes attribute:Stamina dots:2

/attributes attribute:Charisma dots:2
/attributes attribute:Manipulation dots:2
/attributes attribute:Composure dots:3

/attributes attribute:Intelligence dots:3
/attributes attribute:Wits dots:3
/attributes attribute:Resolve dots:2

Auto-calculations: - Health = Stamina + 3 = 5 - Willpower = Resolve + Composure = 5

docs.title: Step 3: Set Your Skills
docs.text:
You have 11 dots to distribute across 27 skills:

Prioritize one category: - Physical skills: 7 dots - Social skills: 4 dots - Mental skills: 0 dots

Or: - Physical: 4 dots - Social: 7 dots - Mental: 0 dots

Or: - Any other combination totaling 11 dots

Detective Maria example (Social/Mental focus): 

/skill_set skill:Firearms dots:3
/skill_set skill:Athletics dots:2
/skill_set skill:Brawl dots:1

/skill_set skill:Insight dots:3
/skill_set skill:Intimidation dots:2
/skill_set skill:Persuasion dots:2

/skill_set skill:Investigation dots:4
/skill_set skill:Awareness dots:3
/skill_set skill:Medicine dots:2

docs.title: Step 4: Add Specialties
docs.text:
Pick 3 specialties for skills you have dots in:

/specialty action:add skill:Investigation specialty:Crime Scenes
/specialty action:add skill:Firearms specialty:Pistols
/specialty action:add skill:Insight specialty:Reading Lies

When you use these: - Roll with the skill as normal - On success, reroll any 1s (once) - Potentially turn failures into successes

docs.title: Step 5: Set Your Identity
docs.text:
/creed creed:Defender
/drive drive:Virtue
/ambition ambition:Protect the neighborhood from all threats
/desire desire:Find and stop the vampire killing locals

These define: - Your philosophical approach (Creed) - What motivates you (Drive) - Your long-term goal (Ambition) - Your immediate focus (Desire)

docs.title: Step 6: Choose Your Starting Edge
docs.text:
Every Hunter gets one Edge to start:

/edge edge:Senses

Senses is great for investigators - it enhances perception and awareness.

Other good starter Edges: - Arsenal - For combat-focused Hunters - Contacts - For social/investigative Hunters - Library - For research-focused Hunters - Fleet - For fast/athletic Hunters

docs.title: Rolling Dice
docs.text:
The Formula: 

Attribute + Skill + Modifiers = Dice Pool

Example: Shooting a Vampire 

Dexterity (3) + Firearms (3) = 6 dice
/roll pool:6 difficulty:2 comment:Shooting the vampire

Success Counting: - 1-5 = Failure - 6-9 = One success each - 10 = One success (can form critical pairs) - Pair of 10s = Critical (+2 additional successes)

docs.title: When to Roll
docs.text:
Combat Actions: - Attack: Dexterity + Firearms (shooting) or Strength/Dexterity + Brawl/Melee (close combat) - Defend: Dexterity + Athletics (dodge) - Soak damage: Stamina + Resolve

Social Actions: - Persuade: Manipulation + Persuasion - Intimidate: Strength or Manipulation + Intimidation - Lie: Manipulation + Subterfuge - Detect lies: Wits + Insight

Mental Actions: - Investigate: Intelligence + Investigation - Research: Intelligence + Academics or Occult - Notice: Wits + Awareness - Remember: Intelligence + relevant skill

docs.title: Using Desperation
docs.text:
What is Desperation? - Your connection to supernatural power (0-10 rating) - Adds extra dice when you need them - Risks Overreach and Despair

How to use it: 

/roll pool:5 difficulty:3 desperate:true comment:Must succeed!

If Desperation = 3, you roll 8 dice total (5 + 3 orange Desperation dice).

The Risk: - Roll 1s on Desperation dice? Enter Overreach or Despair - Success + Desperation 1s = Choose to keep success and gain Danger, or enter Despair - Failure + Desperation 1s = Automatic Despair

When to use Desperation: - Life-or-death situations - Critical story moments - When failure is unacceptable

When NOT to use Desperation: - Routine tasks - Low-stakes situations - When already at high Danger

docs.title: Taking Damage
docs.text:
When you get hurt: 

/damage amount:3 type:lethal

Damage types: - Superficial - Bruises, minor cuts (heals quickly) - Lethal - Serious wounds (heals slowly)

Tracking: - Superficial fills from left - Lethal fills from right - When they meet in the middle, you're incapacitated

Healing: 

/heal amount:2 type:superficial

/skill_set skill:Firearms dots:4
(Costs 8 XP: new rating 4 × 2)

Plan progression: - Save for attributes (expensive: new rating × 4 XP) - Raise key skills (cheaper: new rating × 2 XP) - Add specialties (cheap: 3 XP each) - Buy new Edges or Perks (varies, ask Storyteller)

docs.title: "What attributes should I prioritize?"
docs.text:
Combat-focused: Dexterity (attack) and Stamina (survive) Social-focused: Charisma/Manipulation (influence) and Composure (resist) Investigation-focused: Intelligence (analyze) and Wits (notice)

Everyone needs: At least 2 in their primary attributes.

docs.title: "What skills are most important?"
docs.text:
Universal: - Athletics (dodge, chase, climb) - Awareness (notice threats) - Insight (read people)

Combat: - Firearms (ranged) - Brawl or Melee (close combat)

Investigation: - Investigation (find clues) - Occult (understand monsters)

Social: - Persuasion (convince) - Intimidation (threaten) - Subterfuge (deceive)

docs.title: "How does Desperation work again?"
docs.text:
1. You have a Desperation rating (0-10)
  2. When rolling with desperate:true, add that many extra dice
  3. If those extra dice show 1s, you risk Overreach or Despair
  4. Desperation increases when you use Edges or face darkness
  5. It's power with a price

docs.title: "What's the difference between Creed and Drive?"
docs.text:
• Creed = Your philosophy (how you Hunt)
  • Drive = Your motivation (why you Hunt)
  • Both can be lost if you enter Despair
  • Both can be regained through Redemption

docs.title: "How do I know what to roll?"
docs.text:
Ask your Storyteller: "What do I roll for this?"

Common formula: - Physical task: Physical attribute + Physical skill - Social task: Social attribute + Social skill - Mental task: Mental attribute + Mental skill

docs.title: Playing with Herald
docs.text:
A session-by-session guide to using Herald during Hunter: The Reckoning 5th Edition gameplay.

This guide covers common workflows, scene types, and how to use Herald commands effectively during actual play.

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text:
1. Before the Session
  2. Investigation Scenes
  3. Social Scenes
  4. Combat Scenes
  5. Between Scenes
  6. After the Session
  7. Common Workflows

docs.title: Prepare Your Character
docs.text:
1. Review your sheet: 

/sheet

Know your: - Key dice pools (combat, social, investigation) - Current Health and Willpower - Desperation rating - Active Edges and Perks

2. Check your identity: 

/sheet

Confirm your: - Creed and Drive (are you in Despair?) - Ambition and Desire (what are you pursuing?) - Current Danger level

3. Plan your approach: - What's the session goal? - What's your character's personal goal? - How will you contribute to the cell?

docs.title: Coordinate with Your Cell
docs.text:
Discuss roles: - Who handles combat? - Who leads social interactions? - Who investigates and researches? - Who provides support/healing?

Share information: - What did you learn last session? - What are your current leads? - What resources do you have?

Plan tactics: - How will you approach the threat? - What's your backup plan? - Who takes point in different situations?

docs.title: Searching for Clues
docs.text:
Basic investigation roll: 

/roll pool:7 difficulty:2 comment:Searching the crime scene
(Intelligence + Investigation)

Common investigation pools: - Crime scenes: Intelligence + Investigation - Research: Intelligence + Academics or Occult - Tracking: Wits + Survival - Noticing details: Wits + Awareness - Forensics: Intelligence + Medicine or Science

docs.title: Example Investigation Sequence
docs.text:
Scene: Investigating a vampire's lair

1. Initial survey: 

/roll pool:5 difficulty:2 comment:Looking around the lair
(Wits 3 + Awareness 2)

2. Detailed search: 

/roll pool:7 difficulty:3 comment:Searching for evidence
(Intelligence 3 + Investigation 4)

3. Occult analysis: 

/roll pool:6 difficulty:2 comment:Identifying vampire markings
(Intelligence 3 + Occult 3)

4. Following tracks: 

/roll pool:4 difficulty:3 comment:Tracking the vampire
(Wits 3 + Survival 1)

docs.title: When to Use Desperation
docs.text:
Consider Desperation when: - Time is critical (victim still alive) - Clue is essential to the case - Failure means the trail goes cold

Example: 

/roll pool:7 difficulty:4 desperate:true comment:MUST find where they went!

Risk: - Desperation dice show 1s = Overreach or Despair - Balance urgency against your Danger level

docs.title: Investigation Tips
docs.text:
Before rolling: - Ask the Storyteller what you're looking for - Clarify the difficulty - Describe your approach (might reduce difficulty)

After rolling: - Successes reveal information - Margin of success = depth of information - Failure doesn't mean nothing happens (Storyteller still narrates)

docs.title: Persuasion and Influence
docs.text:
Basic persuasion roll: 

/roll pool:6 difficulty:2 comment:Convincing the witness to talk
(Manipulation + Persuasion)

Common social pools: - Persuade: Manipulation + Persuasion - Intimidate: Strength or Manipulation + Intimidation - Deceive: Manipulation + Subterfuge - Read someone: Wits + Insight - Lead/inspire: Charisma + Leadership - Perform/disguise: Charisma + Performance

docs.title: Example Social Sequence
docs.text:
Scene: Interrogating a suspect who knows about vampires

1. Read their demeanor: 

/roll pool:5 difficulty:2 comment:Sizing up the suspect
(Wits 3 + Insight 2)

2. Build rapport: 

/roll pool:6 difficulty:2 comment:Getting them to trust me
(Charisma 3 + Persuasion 3)

3. Ask the hard questions: 

/roll pool:6 difficulty:3 comment:Pressing for the truth
(Manipulation 2 + Intimidation 4)

4. Detect lies: 

/roll pool:5 difficulty:3 comment:Is he telling the whole truth?
(Wits 3 + Insight 2)

docs.title: Using Edge Perks
docs.text:
Contacts: - Call in favors for information - Leverage your network - Get access to restricted areas

Fame: - Use celebrity status to open doors - Leverage public influence - Manipulate media attention

Status: - Exercise authority - Bypass bureaucracy - Command respect

docs.title: Social Tips
docs.text:
Roleplay first, roll second: - Describe your approach - Good roleplaying may reduce difficulty - Bad approach may increase difficulty

Know when to walk away: - Failed Persuasion doesn't mean try again immediately - Consider different approaches - Come back with new leverage

docs.title: Initiative and Turn Order
docs.text: Storyteller determines initiative: - Usually Wits + Dexterity - Higher rolls act first

docs.title: Attack Rolls
docs.text:
Ranged attack (Firearms): 

/roll pool:7 difficulty:2 comment:Shooting the ghoul
(Dexterity 4 + Firearms 3)

Melee attack: 

/roll pool:5 difficulty:2 comment:Swinging the bat at the vampire
(Strength 3 + Melee 2)

Unarmed attack: 

/roll pool:6 difficulty:2 comment:Punching the cultist
(Strength 3 + Brawl 3)

docs.title: Defense Rolls
docs.text:
Dodge: 

/roll pool:5 difficulty:2 comment:Dodging the vampire's claws
(Dexterity 3 + Athletics 2)

Soak damage: 

/roll pool:4 difficulty:2 comment:Toughing out the hit
(Stamina 2 + Resolve 2)

docs.title: Taking Damage
docs.text:
When hit: 

/damage amount:3 type:lethal

Damage types: - Superficial - Minor wounds, bruises - Lethal - Serious injuries, bleeding

Tracking: - Herald automatically marks your Health track - Superficial fills from left - Lethal fills from right - Incapacitated when they meet

docs.title: Healing in Combat
docs.text:
Quick patch: 

/heal amount:2 type:superficial

Medical attention: 

/roll pool:7 difficulty:2 comment:Field medicine on wounded ally
(Intelligence 3 + Medicine 4)

docs.title: Using Desperation in Combat
docs.text:
Life-or-death moment: 

/roll pool:7 difficulty:3 desperate:true comment:Must kill the vampire leader!

When to use: - You're about to die - Ally is about to die - Critical moment in the fight - Final strike opportunity

Risk: - Desperation 1s = Overreach or Despair - In Despair, you lose your Drive - May enter frenzy or lose control

docs.title: Combat Example Sequence
docs.text:
Round 1:

Hunter 1 (You): 

/roll pool:7 difficulty:2 comment:Shooting vampire
Success! Deal damage.

Hunter 2 (Ally): Attacks with melee weapon.

Vampire: Attacks Hunter 2. 

/damage amount:4 type:lethal

Round 2:

Hunter 1 (You): 

/roll pool:7 difficulty:3 desperate:true comment:Finishing shot!
Using Desperation for extra dice!

Hunter 2 (Ally): 

/heal amount:2 type:superficial
Quick patch between attacks.

Vampire: Flees or dies.

docs.title: Combat Tips
docs.text:
Positioning matters: - Describe your tactics - Cover provides bonuses - High ground helps - Flanking may reduce difficulty

Focus fire: - Multiple Hunters attack one threat - Eliminate enemies quickly - Protect wounded allies

Know when to retreat: - Low Health = run - Out of Willpower = run - High Danger + Desperation = don't use Desperation - Sometimes survival is victory

docs.title: Managing Resources
docs.text:
Check your status: 

/sheet

Review: - Health (heal if needed) - Willpower (spend carefully) - Desperation (rising or stable?) - Danger (too high = risk Despair)

Heal between fights: 

/heal amount:3 type:superficial

Recover Willpower: - Storyteller awards Willpower for good roleplay - Fulfilling Ambition/Desire - Pursuing Drive

docs.title: Raising Danger
docs.text:
When Danger increases: 

/danger amount:+2
(Storyteller tracks this when you Overreach)

When Danger decreases: 

/danger amount:-1
(Storyteller may allow this in downtime)

Monitor carefully: - High Danger = risky to use Desperation - Danger 8+ = extremely dangerous - Reduce through rest and Redemption

docs.title: Planning Next Steps
docs.text:
Discuss with your cell: - What did we learn? - Where do we go next? - What resources do we need? - Who do we need to talk to?

Use your Edges: - Library: Research the threat - Contacts: Call for information - Arsenal: Acquire weapons - Safehouse: Plan in safety

docs.title: Experience Points
docs.text:
Storyteller awards XP: 

/xp action:view

Common XP awards: - Session attendance: 1-2 XP - Accomplishments: 1-3 XP - Good roleplay: 1 XP - Advancing the chronicle: 1-2 XP

Total typical: 3-5 XP per session

docs.title: Spending XP
docs.text:
Check your XP: 

/xp action:view

Raise a skill: 

/skill_set skill:Firearms dots:4
Cost: 8 XP (new rating 4 × 2)

Raise an attribute: 

/attributes attribute:Dexterity dots:5
Cost: 20 XP (new rating 5 × 4)

Add a specialty: 

/specialty action:add skill:Investigation specialty:Forensics
Cost: 3 XP

Save for later: - Edges and Perks (10-20 XP) - Major attribute increases - Building toward specific builds

docs.title: XP Strategy
docs.text:
Short-term (0-20 XP): - Buy specialties (3 XP each) - Raise key skills to 3-4 - Fill gaps in your skillset

Mid-term (20-50 XP): - Raise primary skills to 4-5 - Increase secondary attributes - Buy second Edge or Perks

Long-term (50+ XP): - Raise primary attributes to 4-5 - Master your specialty - Optimize your build

docs.title: Session Recap
docs.text:
Update your notes: - NPCs encountered - Clues discovered - Threats identified - Personal character developments

Adjust Ambition/Desire: 

/desire desire:New immediate goal

Plan character progression: - What do I want to improve? - What would help the cell? - What fits my character concept?

docs.title: Investigation Workflow
docs.text:
1. Arrive at scene
  2. /roll Wits + Awareness (initial survey)
  3. /roll Intelligence + Investigation (detailed search)
  4. /roll Intelligence + Occult (identify supernatural elements)
  5. Follow leads (more rolls as needed)
  6. Report findings to cell

docs.title: Social Encounter Workflow
docs.text:
1. Approach NPC
  2. /roll Wits + Insight (read their mood)
  3. Roleplay opening conversation
  4. /roll Charisma/Manipulation + Social skill (persuade, intimidate, etc.)
  5. /roll Wits + Insight (detect lies if suspicious)
  6. Conclude interaction

docs.title: Combat Workflow
docs.text:
1. Initiative determined
  2. Your turn:
  3. Declare action
  4. /roll Dexterity + Combat skill (attack)
  5. Apply damage to enemy
  6. Enemy turn:
  7. /roll Dexterity + Athletics (dodge if targeted)
  8. /damage amount:X type:Y (if hit)
  9. Repeat until combat ends
  10. After combat:
  11. /heal if wounded
  12. Check Desperation/Danger
  13. Loot/investigate

docs.title: Desperation Decision Workflow
docs.text:
1. Face difficult challenge
  2. Assess:
  3. How critical is success?
  4. What's your current Danger?
  5. Can you afford to fail?
  6. Decide:
  7. Use Desperation? /roll pool:X difficulty:Y desperate:true
  8. Or play it safe? /roll pool:X difficulty:Y
  9. If Overreach occurs:
  10. Choose: Keep success + gain Danger
  11. Or: Reject success, enter Despair
  12. If Despair:
  13. /despair (lose Drive)
  14. Plan Redemption path

docs.title: Common Rolls
docs.text:
Investigation: 

/roll pool:7 difficulty:2 comment:Investigating
(Intelligence + Investigation)

Combat (Ranged): 

/roll pool:7 difficulty:2 comment:Shooting
(Dexterity + Firearms)

Combat (Melee): 

/roll pool:5 difficulty:2 comment:Melee attack
(Strength/Dexterity + Melee)

Social (Persuade): 

/roll pool:6 difficulty:2 comment:Persuading
(Manipulation + Persuasion)

Awareness: 

/roll pool:5 difficulty:2 comment:Noticing
(Wits + Awareness)

docs.title: 2. Create Your First Character

Character Created!

docs.title: 3. View Your Character Sheet
